QB.name: Quarterback (QB)
QB.role: The leader of the offense! Throws passes, hands off the ball, and calls plays.
responsibilities: Reads the defense before the snap

FB.name: Fullback (FB)
FB.role: A powerful blocking back who leads the way for the running back.
responsibilities: Runs the ball on short yardage plays

HB.name: Halfback/Running Back (HB/RB)
HB.role: The primary ball carrier who runs with the ball.
responsibilities: Runs with the ball when handed off

WR.name: Wide Receiver (WR)
WR.role: Catches passes from the quarterback and gains yards.
responsibilities: Runs precise routes to get open
Runs after the catch for extra yards

TE.name: Tight End (TE)
TE.role: A mix between a receiver and an offensive lineman.
responsibilities: Lines up next to the offensive line

LT.name: Left Tackle (LT)
LT.role: Protects the quarterback's blind side - the most important offensive lineman.
responsibilities: Blocks edge rushers on the left side
Protects quarterback's blind side (for right-handed QBs)

LG.name: Left Guard (LG)
LG.role: Protects the quarterback and creates running lanes on the left side.
responsibilities: Pulls to lead block on runs

C.name: Center (C)
C.role: Snaps the ball to start every play and protects the QB.
responsibilities: Snaps the ball to the quarterback

RG.name: Right Guard (RG)
RG.role: Protects the quarterback and creates running lanes on the right side.
responsibilities: Pulls to lead block on runs

RT.name: Right Tackle (RT)
RT.role: Big blocker who protects the right edge.
responsibilities: Blocks edge rushers on the right side

DE.name: Defensive End (DE)
DE.role: Rushes the quarterback from the edge and contains running plays.
responsibilities: Rushes the passer from the edge
Sets the edge on running plays

DT.name: Defensive Tackle (DT)
DT.role: Plugs the middle and stops the run up the gut.

MLB.name: Middle Linebacker (MLB)
MLB.role: The quarterback of the defense - calls plays and makes tackles.
responsibilities: Stops the run up the middle
Covers tight ends and running backs

OLB.name: Outside Linebacker (OLB)
OLB.role: Versatile defender who covers, rushes, and tackles on the outside.
responsibilities: Covers tight ends and running backs

CB.name: Cornerback (CB)
CB.role: Covers wide receivers and defends passes.

FS.name: Free Safety (FS)
FS.role: The center fielder of football - provides deep coverage help.

SS.name: Strong Safety (SS)
SS.role: Physical safety who plays closer to the line and stops the run.

penalties.name: Holding
penalties.explanation: Holding occurs when a player grabs or restrains an opponent to prevent them from moving freely.
penalties.commonSituation: Often called on offensive linemen trying to stop pass rushers

penalties.name: False Start
penalties.explanation: A false start happens when an offensive player moves before the ball is snapped.
penalties.commonSituation: Usually occurs when a lineman flinches or moves too early

penalties.name: Offsides
penalties.explanation: Offsides occurs when a defensive player crosses the line of scrimmage before the ball is snapped.
penalties.commonSituation: Defensive players trying to time the snap perfectly

penalties.name: Pass Interference
penalties.explanation: Pass interference is called when a defender makes illegal contact with a receiver while the ball is in the air.
penalties.commonSituation: Defender grabs, pushes, or impedes a receiver's ability to catch the ball

penalties.name: Face Mask
penalties.explanation: A face mask penalty occurs when a player grabs another player's face mask, which is dangerous.
penalties.commonSituation: Often happens during tackles when players accidentally grab the face mask

penalties.name: Roughing the Passer
penalties.explanation: Roughing the passer is called when a defender hits the quarterback after they've thrown the ball.
penalties.commonSituation: Protects quarterbacks from late hits that could cause injury

quizzes.question: A defensive player grabs the jersey of a receiver running a route. What's the penalty?
quizzes.explanation: Pass interference is when a defender illegally contacts a receiver while the ball is in the air!

quizzes.question: Which position snaps the ball to start every play?
quizzes.explanation: The Center snaps the ball to the quarterback to start every offensive play!

quizzes.question: Who is called the 'quarterback of the defense'?
quizzes.explanation: The Middle Linebacker calls defensive plays and adjustments, just like a QB leads the offense!

quizzes.question: How many points is a touchdown worth?
quizzes.explanation: A touchdown is worth 6 points! Teams can then try for 1 or 2 extra points.

quizzes.question: What is it called when the defense tackles the offense in their own end zone?
quizzes.explanation: A Safety is worth 2 points for the defense! It's rare but exciting when it happens.

quizzes.question: How many downs (chances) does the offense get to move 10 yards?
quizzes.explanation: The offense gets 4 tries to move the ball 10 yards. If they succeed, they get 4 more downs!

quizzes.question: How many players from each team are on the field during a play?
quizzes.explanation: Each team has exactly 11 players on the field, making 22 total players!

quizzes.question: An offensive lineman moves before the ball is snapped. What's the penalty?
quizzes.explanation: False Start is when an offensive player moves before the snap. It's a 5-yard penalty.

quizzes.question: Which offensive position is a mix between a receiver and a lineman?
quizzes.explanation: The Tight End blocks like a lineman but can also catch passes like a receiver!

quizzes.question: In which formation does the QB line up 5 yards behind the center?
quizzes.explanation: The Shotgun formation puts the QB further back for better passing visibility!

quizzes.question: How long is a football field from end zone to end zone?
quizzes.explanation: The playing field is 100 yards, plus 10 yards for each end zone = 120 yards total!

quizzes.question: How many quarters are in a football game?
quizzes.explanation: A football game has 4 quarters, each 15 minutes long (12 minutes in high school)!

quizzes.question: Which position is known for protecting the quarterback's blind side?
quizzes.explanation: The Left Tackle protects a right-handed QB's blind side - it's one of the most important positions!

quizzes.question: Which defensive formation has 4 down linemen and 3 linebackers?
quizzes.explanation: The 4-3 Defense is the most common formation with 4 linemen and 3 linebackers!

quizzes.question: What is it called when a team kicks the ball away on 4th down?
quizzes.explanation: A Punt kicks the ball far away to the other team, giving them worse field position!

learningGoals.text: Watch and analyze a full game

facts.label: Field Length
facts.explanation: The playing field is 100 yards long, divided into yard lines every 5 yards

facts.label: End Zones
facts.explanation: Each end zone is 10 yards deep. Total field length including end zones is 120 yards

facts.label: Field Width
facts.explanation: The field is 160 feet wide (53 and 1/3 yards)

facts.label: Hash Marks
facts.explanation: Hash marks show where the ball is placed. In the NFL they're 70 feet 9 inches apart

facts.label: Goal Posts
facts.explanation: Goal posts are at the back of each end zone, 10 feet high with a crossbar

facts.label: Quarters
facts.explanation: Each game has 4 quarters of 15 minutes each (12 minutes in high school)

facts.label: Halftime
facts.explanation: Break between 2nd and 3rd quarters (longer for college/NFL, shorter for youth)

facts.label: Downs
facts.explanation: The offense gets 4 tries (downs) to move the ball 10 yards. If successful, they get 4 more downs

facts.label: Play Clock
facts.explanation: Teams have 40 seconds to start the next play (25 seconds after certain stoppages)

facts.label: Game Clock
facts.explanation: Clock stops for incomplete passes, out of bounds, timeouts, penalties, and scores

facts.label: Team Timeouts
facts.explanation: Each team gets 3 timeouts per half. Unused timeouts don't carry over to the 2nd half

facts.label: Timeout Length
facts.explanation: TV timeouts are longer (about 2 minutes), but team timeouts are 30 seconds

facts.label: Two-Minute Warning
facts.explanation: Automatic timeout at 2:00 remaining in each half (NFL only, not college/high school)

facts.label: Coach Challenges
facts.explanation: Coaches can challenge referee calls. If they win both challenges, they get a 3rd

facts.label: Challenge Rules
facts.explanation: To challenge a play, you must have a timeout remaining. If you lose, you lose the timeout

facts.label: Touchdown (TD)
facts.explanation: Ball crosses the goal line in the end zone. Most valuable way to score!

facts.label: Extra Point (PAT)
facts.explanation: After TD: Kick through goal posts (1 pt) or run/pass into end zone from 2-yard line (2 pts)

facts.label: Field Goal (FG)
facts.explanation: Kicker kicks ball through goal posts from anywhere on the field

facts.label: Safety
facts.explanation: Defense tackles ball carrier in their own end zone. Rare but exciting!

facts.label: Two-Point Conversion
facts.explanation: Instead of kicking extra point, team tries to get ball in end zone from 2-yard line

facts.label: Kickoff
facts.explanation: Game begins with kickoff. Kicking team kicks from their 35-yard line

facts.label: First Down
facts.explanation: Offense needs to gain 10 yards in 4 tries to earn a new set of 4 downs

facts.label: Turnover
facts.explanation: If offense doesn't get 10 yards in 4 downs, other team gets the ball. Also happens on interceptions and fumbles

facts.label: Punt
facts.explanation: On 4th down, teams often punt to kick the ball far away, giving it to the other team

facts.label: Overtime
facts.explanation: If game is tied after 4 quarters, teams play overtime. Rules vary by league (NFL, college, high school)

facts.label: Players on Field
facts.explanation: Each team has exactly 11 players on the field at all times (22 total)

facts.label: NFL Roster
facts.explanation: NFL teams can have 53 players on their active roster

facts.label: Game Day Active
facts.explanation: Of the 53 roster players, only 46 can be active and dress for each game

facts.label: Three Units
facts.explanation: Teams have separate units: offense (score points), defense (stop other team), special teams (kicks)

facts.label: Substitutions
facts.explanation: Teams can substitute players freely between plays, but all 11 must be set before snap

offense.name: I-Formation
offense.description: Classic power running formation with FB directly in front of HB
offense.whenToUse: Short yardage situations, power running game

offense.name: Shotgun Formation
offense.description: QB lines up 5 yards behind center for better passing visibility

offense.name: Spread Formation
offense.description: Multiple receivers spread across the field to create space

offense.name: Pro Set
offense.description: Balanced formation with two backs side-by-side behind QB

defense.name: 4-3 Defense
defense.description: Four down linemen and three linebackers - most common defense
defense.whenToUse: Standard defensive formation, good against run and pass

defense.name: 3-4 Defense
defense.description: Three down linemen and four linebackers - versatile and unpredictable
defense.whenToUse: When you want more flexibility in blitzing

defense.name: Nickel Defense
defense.description: Removes a linebacker, adds a 5th defensive back for passing situations
defense.whenToUse: Obvious passing downs, need more coverage

defense.name: Cover 2 (Tampa 2)
defense.description: Two safeties split the deep field in half, cornerbacks play underneath
defense.whenToUse: Prevent deep passes, force short completions
